description: List consisting of the representation of n in base 3 using -1,0,1 for n=1,2,3,4,...
comments: Every natural number n has a unique representation as n = sum i=1 ... k e(i)*(3^i) for some k where e(i) is one of -1,0,1. Example: 25 = 27-3+1= 1*3^3+0*3^2+(-1)*3^1+1*3^0 so its representation is 1,0,-1,1. So by writing n in this base 3 representation and juxtaposing we get the sequence: (1),(1,-1),(1,0),(1,1),(1,-1,-1),...
references: D. E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, Vol 2, pp 173-175.
formula: n = Sum(a(A134421(n)-2-k)*3^k: 0 <= k < A134021(n)), for n>0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 25 2007
